ALLEGATION:
It was alleged that a minor visitor slipped a pair of crafting scissors to a resident
during a supervised visit at the facility. The scissors were later found in the
resident's community bathroom on the unit.
INVESTIGATION:
Resident E, age 17, is an MCI ward. She was removed from her biological parents as
an infant and adopted together with her three siblings. At age 13, Resident E was
removed from her adoptive mother’s care due to abuse/neglect. She was placed with
her biological aunt in Texas and then removed for assaulting the aunt. Resident E was
placed on probation in the home of her adult sister, age 26. Three months ago, she
said she was removed from her sister’s care for “skipping school” and placed at Vista
Maria. On 1/6/20, Resident E’s adult sister threatened to harm Vista Maria staff and
was taken off of her visitor list. At the time of this incident, Adult Visitor 1 was the only
person on Resident E’s visitor list. On the list, Adult Visitor 1 is identified as an “aunt”
who requires “supervised” visits.
Resident E was interviewed regarding the incident that occurred on 1/11/20. She
clarified that she and Adult Visitor 1 are not blood relatives. Adult Visitor 1 is actually
her sister’s boyfriend’s sister, but Resident E just refers to her as “aunt.”
On 1/11/20, Resident E said she had five visitors at Vista Maria. She listed Adult Visitor
1; Child Visitor 2, age 14; Child Visitor 3, age 9; Child Visitor 4, age 5; and Child Visitor
5, age 2. Resident E referred to the 14-year-old as Adult Visitor 1’s daughter. She said
the three younger children are her own biological nieces and nephew.
I obtained Resident E’s visitor log. For the visit that took place on 1/11/20, Adult Visitor
1 was the only name signed in on the log. The name of the staff or supervisor who
signed her in was left blank. I obtained Resident E’s approved visitor list. There were
no Child Visitors on the list.
I asked Resident E about what happened during the visit on 1/11/20. She said Staff 1
supervised it by sitting inside of the visiting room the entire time. As the visitors were
leaving the building, Adult Visitor 1 stopped at the staff office. At that point, Resident E
said Child Visitor 2 took crafting scissors from her pocket and handed them to her.
Resident E tucked the scissors into the waist of her pants. I asked if Resident E and
Child Visitor 2 had preplanned this exchange. She said they did not.
Before returning to the wing, Resident E said Staff 1 “checked her in” by popping the
back of her bra, having her pull the front of her own bra and empty her pants pockets,
which is the normal “check-in” process. Staff 1 did not see the scissors tucked in her
pants.
3

I asked Resident E what she did with the scissors. Initially she said she hid them in her
room under her pillow. Then she put them back in her pants and hid them inside of the
sink in the community bathroom. “I told a peer I had it…Staff found it.”
After the scissors were located by staff, Vista Maria contacted the Dearborn Heights
Police Department to report the incident. Resident E provided a written statement to the
police.
Staff 1 was interviewed with the facility Rights Advisor present. She has worked at the
facility for 16 months. When Resident E’s visit began, Staff 1 said Team Leader 1 was
on duty. Staff 1 volunteered to supervise the visit. During the visit, she said Child
Visitor 2 “gave me a snarky look and appeared older than age 14.” She heard Adult
Visitor 1 remark that Child Visitor 2 may someday “end up at Vista Maria.”
When visiting time ended, Staff 1 said she exited the room behind Resident E. Adult
Visitor 1 waited at the staff office for her purse and the Child Visitors hugged Resident E
goodbye in the hallway. The visit spanned across two shifts. Staff 1 said she did not
know which supervisor allowed the visitors into the building or visiting room.
Vista Maria’s visiting policy indicates the supervisor or designee:
1. Checks visiting plan to ensure visitor is on approved list.
2. Verifies visitor identification.
3. Asks visitor to sign Visitor Log form (#732) and ensures no unnecessary or
contraband items are brought into the visiting area.
4. If all conditions are met, shows visitor to a private visiting area and informs client of
visitor’s arrival.
5. Before visit, checks client and area to ensure no inappropriate materials are present.
6. Monitors length of visit.
7. After visit, checks client and area to ensure no inappropriate materials are present.
8. Signs all visitors out from unit on Visitor Log.
9. Designates an assigned staff if needed for a supervised visit.
The staff person assigned to supervise the visit:
1. Sits in visiting area to effectively monitor the physical and verbal interactions between
the resident and visitors.
2. Documents behavioral observations between the resident and all visitors on
Supervised Visitation Form.
3. Redirects resident or visitors of any inappropriate behaviors and notifies Supervisor.
Currently Vista Maria’s visiting policy does not prohibit fictive kin, non-family members,
children of any age or any number of people from visiting at one time. It seems Vista
Maria routinely allows both related and unrelated minors inside of its residential
4

buildings without verifying their identity. The policy does not address how staff are to
handle minor visitors. This policy needs to be revised.
Technical Assistance
It is strongly suggested that Vista Maria consider restricting visitors to parents/
guardians/attorneys/clergy and those who are ordered visits by the Court. Minors may
be restricted unless a monthly sibling visit is required by DHHS and Vista Maria is able
to verify the identity of the sibling(s). It is suggested that perspective adoptive and/or
foster parents be encouraged to schedule a family therapy session with the resident and
her therapist.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: An unidentified Supervisor or Team Leader allowed four minors
to visit Resident E. The minors were not on her approved visitor
list. Allowing unverified children to visit residents appears to be
done across Vista’s campus as a matter of routine.
The existing policy indicates the supervisor is supposed to verify
the visitor’s identity. However, it is uncommon for minor children
to carry ID. Vista Maria’s policy does not address how staff are
to handle child visitors.
Staff 1 supervised Resident E’s visit according to the visiting
policy. However, Resident E reported that Child Visitor 2
slipped her a pair of crafting scissors when they hugged good-
bye in the hallway after the visit ended.
The scissors were not found when the resident was searched
before entering the wing.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is received, I recommend this facility
continue its current licensing status.
